discourse_list.title: How much DAI is needed to get the peg back to 1:1

content.content: As a follow-on to the general theme a discussion surrounding the peg and to get an idea of why intense action may be justified, please the below informal poll (not a signal request) How much DAI needs to be minted in order to get DAI back to $1.00 as measured with a 14d trailing average?     1MM - 5MM 25MM -50MM 100MM -150MM 200MM - 500MM 750MM - 1Bn more     0 voters     similar to the above once the above 1:1 is achieved, How much further should we internationally overshoot before we start to use the DSR to cause the demand  (instead of tapping the breaks on DAI issuance)? Starting at     $1.00000 $0.99999 $0.99990 $0.99900 $0.99000 $0.98000 $0.95000     0 voters
content.GPT-summary: The author of the post is asking for feedback on how much DAI needs to be minted to get DAI back to $1.00 as measured with a 14d trailing average. They are also asking how much further should they internationally overshoot before they start to use the DSR to cause the demand. The post is asking for opinions and feedback from the readers.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is asking for feedback

content.content: I said 200-500m. But I’d say in the upper range. Much closer to 500M+ DAI needed. At least 350m is needed to reach 1.0 And the lower price might cause more demand. 2nd question is a bit weird since I don’t really think it’s the DSR to stimulate demand, the main lever is raising the SF to curb supply. I said $0.99 because nowadays with all the AMMs market making DAI, $0.99 is quite significant. It takes a lot to go from $1->$0.99. Not that I’m expecting us to reach $0.99 anytime soon. A bit of wishful thinking that we’ll break 1.0.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party extending to proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
None of the topics listed match

content.content: Jiecut:  the main lever is raising the SF to curb supply.   We have start using the risk premiums based on the risk alone… It really should be divorced from monetary policy.     Jiecut:  I don’t really think it’s the DSR to stimulate demand   It is specifically the goal of the DSR to reduce the traded supply of DAI by removing it from circulation. It has a demand impact when a return is generated from it.     Jiecut:  A bit of wishful thinking that we’ll break 1.0.   We will. As RWA are brought on, it is just a question of when, what scale, and what pace.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is asking for feedback
None of the topics listed match

content.content: Please add multiple choice next time. I’d like to choose more than one option as I’m torn between 2.
Will do! Probably a good idea to start doing this informal poll quarterly (or even monthly).
If only there was someone who could give us a weekly report on the “state of the peg”

mrabino1:  We have start using the risk premiums based on the risk alone… It really should be divorced from monetary policy.   There’s still the base rate. Unless you’re saying all stability fees will be fixed.     mrabino1:  It is specifically the goal of the DSR to reduce the traded supply of DAI by removing it from circulation. It has a demand impact when a return is generated from it.   IMO the DSR is quite a weak lever considering all the yield farming going on. I’m speculating that the SF/(base rate) going from 0% to 5% has a much bigger impact then DSR going from 0% to 5%.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Fair points. The acronyms RP and SF and then base rate get used a lot. From my sense, I am referencing the aggregate cost of capital to the borrower. On a per collateral basis, the cost of capital should be known (and only really change when the risks associated with that collateral shift) and then the DSR crosses all collateral. At least this was the last cycle of what I understood. There are discussions about removing the base rate. @Primoz no doubt has a better handle on that.     Jiecut:  IMO the DSR is quite a weak lever considering all the yield farming going on.   I am no expert on yield farming. However with any inefficient market that generates a yield (e.g. algo trading)… the incremental returns decline over time. The DSR however, really is not trying to compete in that space. As a synthetic US Dollar, it can be marketed and acquired by anyone wishing to do commerce and earn a core return (which is probably better than many other currencies vs. their local inflation).
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is asking for feedback
None of the topics listed match

content.content: I think this should be more specific when it comes to timeline. If I dump 100M Dai onto the market tomorrow, I’d bet we get under the peg on most venues. If you want Dai to remain sustainably under the peg, that’s a different story.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Fair point. Lets amend with the notion that the measurement would be the trailing 14d avg.

I don’t see the point of those questions. Whatever you do, you have to do it continuously. The design of MakerDAO must be changed to be able to control the DAI price in all circumstances. If you want numbers - look at the USDC+USDT market cap from about 6 months ago and now. The second question makes even less sense to me. We don’t overshoot intentionally.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: g_dip:  I think this should be more specific when it comes to timeline. If I dump 100M Dai onto the market tomorrow, I’d bet we get under the peg on most venues.   AMM’s can absorb 300M+ of DAI and we won’t go under the peg.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Interesting. @Jiecut ,  do you have a sense on the breakdown between AMM that produce DAI vs those that consume it (and then trade for other tokens)? I am trying to gauge how unique yETH was in the big picture of things.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is asking for feedback

content.content: bit:  I don’t see the point of those questions.   I believe it is fair to say that we need more DAI supply in the market to rebalance the supply and demand to push the DAI price to 1:1 …     bit:  The second question makes even less sense to me. We don’t overshoot intentionally.   As for the question on when to start the DSR, if we start increasing it right when we hit 1.00000 it will all come down to the “inertia” of the price coming down. We may have an excess of supply such that we may need to start anticipating at 1.0005 … likewise, if the inertia is minimal, we should probably overshoot a bit such that after we increase the DSR we have room to have the price go back up to 1:1 …
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is asking for feedback

content.content: I was hoping this was a multiple choice.  I picked 500-800 when I really wanted 200-500. On the overshoot we wouldn’t use DSR I think we’d want to use SF and raise some funds. I don’t want to see a DSR return until the SF is like 2-4% and sustained so I abstain from the second vote just because of what what used to sop up liquidity.   In general however we do it I’d like to overshoot to .99 if we could just to prove we can provide enough liquidity.   With USDC selling DAI we won’t get to .99 - maybe .999 after perhaps 100M DAI-USDC changed hands - at least.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
None of the topics listed match
None of the topics listed match

content.content: I think it should be around 500 million. The current market SF should be maintained above 2%, there is no reason to continue to maintain SF =0. The idea that SF=0 can help restore PEG has proven to be a mistake.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Agreed- we need the SF at 2-4% for all major assets before we re-institute the DSR.

hongbiao_li:  The current market SF should be maintained above 2%, there is no reason to continue to maintain SF =0. The idea that SF=0 can help restore PEG has proven to be a mistake.   The stability fees had to be reduced to incentivize DAI minting. Had the SFs been increased, the peg would have been much higher.

not when we have PSM and lower LR on stablecoins to create direct arbitrage opportunities.  Then people will mint dai to fix peg despite the SF because its still profitable.  Look at whats happening with USDC right now and we are finally getting good income for MKR from it.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party extending to proposal
3rd party auditing and reviewing proposal

content.content: The market is flooded with farmers. Just look at what happened to USDC-B and you will know how trivial it is to charge them 2% SF. I insist that SF=0 does not help solve PEG. The fact is also true.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Let’s frame it in the reverse. I believe we would be on the same page if we were to contemplate having the SF be 1000% that it would strongly motivate folks to close their Vaults. Yes? If so, then the opposite is true that be reducing the SF we incentivize Vaults to be opened. Right now we are dealing w/ a yield farming phenomena and a loose (intentional) monetary policy, unlike last year that required tightening. Most all of these issue point to the need for additional “tools in the toolbox” to a address the situation. To your point, if the only DAI users are those that are farmers, they are going to be price inelastic showing virtually complete indifference to a rate change. That said, there is a subset of users that are the yield farmers, not all.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is asking for feedback

content.content: Changed my 500MM vote, it seems to be more 1B now
I have closed these informal polls. Weighted average responses.  Newly minted DAI needed to stabilize the peg = ~$545MM DAI price needed before we use the DSR = ~0.988805
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is asking for feedback

content.content: Wouldn’t you say the current situation is novel enough that we should experiment? There is a demand curve from 0% sf to 10000% SF but we don’t know what shape it has. It could be extremely flat at first. Meaning the bottleneck could be the DC/LR for quite some time.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

discourse_list.title: [Informal Poll] How much DAI is needed to get the peg back to 1:1 (November 2020)

content.content: As a follow-on to the previous informal-poll(s) and general discussion surrounding the peg and to get an idea of why intense action may be justified, please see the below informal poll (not a signal request). September 2020 Poll How much DAI needs to be minted in order to get DAI back to $1.00 (as measured with a 14d trailing average)?     1MM - 24MM 25MM - 49MM 50MM -149MM 150MM - 299MM 300MM - 499MM 500MM - 999MM 1Bn - 1.499Bn 1.5Bn - 2Bn more     0 voters     similar to the above Once the above 1:1 is achieved, how much further should we internationally overshoot before we start to use the DSR to cause the demand (instead of tapping the breaks on DAI issuance)?     $1.00000 $0.99999 $0.99990 $0.99900 $0.99000 $0.98000 $0.95000     0 voters     This informal poll will run for a week.
content.GPT-summary: The post is an informal poll asking for feedback on how much DAI needs to be minted to get DAI back to $1.00 and how much further it should overshoot before using the DSR. The author is explaining the purpose of the poll and seeking input from the community. There is no advertising or collaboration request, and no entirely positive or negative feedback is given.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: Would like to see $0.995 in the second vote as that’s what I’d like to see
next time… it will be included…
Contrary to the usual polling guidelines, I think it’s funny that we can’t vote for more than one choice. Kudos to the poll designer.

mrabino1:  This informal poll will run for a week.   Wow thanks for this poll. I find it amazing that I blindly voted for the two values that are currently receiving most votes!  500-999 0.99  Feels good to know that the community thinks more or less like me.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving entirely positive feedback on proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: I don’t see any purpose with these polls. The problem is not in “how much” and we’re not doing anything to encourage minting DAI anyway (like 0% or negative fees). We will never see $1.00 DAI again with this version of DAI unless:  something really bad happens to DAI or DAI becomes backed by USDC to the extent that it is basically USDC.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: psychonaut:  Contrary to the usual polling guidelines, I think it’s funny that we can’t vote for more than one choice. Kudos to the poll designer.    I especially like it since it forces me to choose between 0.99999 and 1.00.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: What is the game theory that makes it preferable for MKR holders to issue DSR rather than cranking up the stability fee and earning protocol revenue?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: the risk didn’t change… therefore the risk premium shouldn’t change… the DSR should mop up the excess supply if the community searches to extract maximum revenue instead of optimizing for risk, the whole project will be displaced, just a question of when. The borrowers (users) are not captive. they can get a line somewhere else.

A couple of things although I’m not sure that either have anything to do with game theory when people borrow money they don’t like their rates going up. DSR basically allows MKR holders to incentivize people to find DAI and take it off the market. I’d look at the later as a sort of marketing expense. The more people you can get interested in holding dai the more loans you hopefully can make.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: I would like to add that various entities ranging from exchanges to legacy applications used by millions integrated DSR… But don’t get any benefit right now because it’s 0%. So it not only increases potential users but also allows Dai to be more competitive among stablecoin.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Doo:  I would like to add that various entities ranging from exchanges to legacy applications used by millions integrated DSR… But don’t get any benefit right now because it’s 0%.   100%. I expect the DSR to be far more potent than the first round of usage and ever more as as integrations expand.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is asking for feedback
None of the topics listed match

content.content: This informal poll has now closed. Below are the weighted average results: How much DAI needs to be minted in order to get DAI back to $1.00?  761.375MM DAI  Once the above 1:1 is achieved, how much further should intentionally overshoot before we start to use the DSR to cause the demand (instead of tapping the breaks on DAI issuance)?  0.9947 DAI
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is asking for feedback

content.content: Between yield generating assets and RWA we will get there soon

I also think that we might get there soon, but it will be because DAI is more and more similar to USDC, so no need for a premium anymore. Right now DAI is very dependent on USDC which dictates its price and its income (we are not free to change the SF anymore without being undercollateralized). If the yield generating assets+ETH+RWA become more popular collateral than USDC, I might change my mind.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
None of the topics listed match
None of the topics listed match

content.content: This topic was automatically closed 91 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
